newsitem.title: UK: Shell's Forcados barrels take pressure off - trade.
newsitem.headline: Shell's Forcados barrels take pressure off - trade.

text.p: Shell has a cushion of about 1.8 million barrels of Forcados crude oil to act as a shield against potential supply disruption caused by the occupation of some of its Niger delta pumping stations at the weekend, traders said on Monday.
Shell said it had been forced to reduce output by about 100,000 barrels per day (bpd) since Saturday because of the incident, but exports in March would be unaffected.
Traders said the oil giant had two standard-sized cargoes of 900,000 barrels of Forcados, one due to load in the next two or three days and the other at the end of March.
The oil was expected to end up on one very large crude carrier with capacity for 1.8 million barrels.
The two cargoes were handed back to Nigeria earlier in March by a lifter unable to sell it profitably in a weakening market.
Traders said it was not immediately clear on what basis Shell had claim to the oil.
It might be part of its equity stake "but if (Nigerian state oil company) NNPC asks the equity holder to get rid of some Forcados it will take care of it," a trader said.
"What's clear is that this will help their (Shell's) marketing of Forcados," the trader said.
Shell officials were not immediately available for comment.
Shell produces almost half of Nigeria's two million barrels per day of crude oil.
